title: BBC Executives Face Parliamentary Scrutiny Over Resignations and Editorial Issues
summary: Senior BBC executives, including Michael Prescott and Samir Shah, are set to be questioned by Members of Parliament (MPs) from the Culture, Media and Sport Committee. This hearing follows a series of crises at the BBC, triggered by the leak of an internal memo from Prescott that highlighted editorial concerns, such as the editing of a Donald Trump speech in a Panorama episode, which combined two sections and was later apologized for by Shah. The memo also pointed to broader issues like bias in BBC Arabic's coverage of the Israel-Gaza war and one-sided reporting on trans issues. These revelations led to the resignations of Director General Tim Davie and Head of News Deborah Turness, and more recently, board member Shumeet Banerji resigned over governance problems, increasing pressure on Chairman Shah. The committee, chaired by Caroline Dinenage, aims to investigate these events, assess the BBC's journalism standards, and discuss ways to rebuild public trust amid accusations of institutional bias and political interference. This situation has sparked a wider debate about the future and integrity of the BBC's news output.

background_read: The BBC, or British Broadcasting Corporation, is a public service broadcaster in the UK funded largely by a television license fee. It is expected to provide impartial and accurate news, but has faced criticism over biases and editorial mistakes. Recently, internal disputes and leaked documents have highlighted issues like the mishandling of reports on political figures and conflicts, leading to high-level resignations. Parliamentary committees often step in to oversee such matters, especially when public trust is at stake, as the BBC plays a key role in British media and democracy. This hearing is part of efforts to ensure accountability and improve standards.
